approved_indications: adults with moderately-to-severely active rheumatoid arthritis

source.title: Rapid response of lichen planus to baricitinib associated with suppression of cytotoxic CXCL13+CD8+ T cells.

patient_population.description: 12 patients with cutaneous LP, mean age 63.6 years, 91.7% female, 75% White, mean disease duration 26.5 months, all had refractory disease

treatment.dose: 2 mg daily for 16 weeks, with optional dose escalation to 4 mg daily for additional 12 weeks
treatment.duration: 16 weeks primary treatment period, with optional 12-week dose escalation

efficacy.time_to_response: As early as week 1 in 37.5% of patients, 100% of patients by week 12
efficacy.duration_of_response: Treatment effects were sustained at week 20 (4 weeks off therapy)
efficacy.effect_size_description: Large effect size with 83.3% response rate, 5 patients completely clear (PGA=0), 5 almost clear (PGA=1)
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Treatment response defined as physician global assessment (PGA) scores of 0-3 with ≥50% score reduction at week 16
efficacy.endpoint_result: 10 of 12 patients (83.3%) achieved treatment response at week 16
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib demonstrated high efficacy in cutaneous lichen planus with 83.3% of patients achieving treatment response. Significant improvements were seen in lesion count, body surface area affected, pruritus, pain, and quality of life measures. Response was sustained 4 weeks after treatment discontinuation.

safety.safety_summary: Treatment was well tolerated with 12 total adverse events, mostly mild or moderate. Only one mild AE was deemed probably related to study drug (neutropenia). No adverse events led to discontinuation of baricitinib.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib showed rapid and sustained response in refractory cutaneous lichen planus with molecular evidence of suppression of cytotoxic CXCL13+CD8+ T cells and IFN signaling.

epidemiology.prevalence_source: Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology and Explorys database

top_treatments.notes: Off-label, most commonly prescribed (97.8% of dermatologists)
Off-label, used by 67.7% of dermatologists
Off-label, used by 64.8% of dermatologists
Off-label, used by 50.6% of dermatologists
Off-label, used by 40.7% of dermatologists
Off-label, used by 33.3% of dermatologists

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: Ruxolitinib cream shows promise in treating lichen planus and is being investigated
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Stepwise approach starting with topical corticosteroids as first-line, followed by topical calcineurin inhibitors, intralesional steroids, then systemic immunosuppressants and phototherapy for refractory cases
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: No FDA-approved treatments exist for lichen planus, despite 25.6% of dermatologists mistakenly believing approved treatments are available. Significant variability in management practices without standardized guidelines.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Lichen planus has no FDA-approved therapies, with treatment relying entirely on off-label use of topical and systemic immunosuppressive agents. The lack of approved treatments and standardized guidelines represents a significant unmet need for this relatively common dermatologic condition affecting predominantly women over 60.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape - Survey Identifies Gaps in Lichen Planus Management, https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/survey-identifies-gaps-lichen-planus-management-2025a1000a90

source.title: Effectiveness of Baricitinib in Refractory Seronegative Rheumatoid Arthritis and Uveitis: A Case Report

patient_population.description: 35-year-old man with seronegative rheumatoid arthritis complicated by bilateral severe non-granulomatous panuveitis

efficacy.duration_of_response: 2 years and 7 months with no relapse observed
efficacy.effect_size_description: Complete resolution of vitreous opacity, serous retinal detachment, anterior chamber cells, and corneal infiltrative lesions
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Improvement in uveitis inflammatory activity
efficacy.endpoint_result: Complete improvement in vitreous opacity, serous retinal detachment, and anterior chamber cells
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib achieved complete resolution of refractory uveitis symptoms including vitreous opacity, serous retinal detachment, and anterior chamber cells within 3 months. The response was sustained for 2 years and 7 months without relapse, while maintaining good visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes.

safety.safety_summary: No serious side effects of oral baricitinib were observed or reported during the 2 years and 7 months treatment period. The patient tolerated the medication well with no adverse events requiring discontinuation.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib was effective for refractory uveitis associated with seronegative rheumatoid arthritis when conventional DMARDs and TNF-α inhibitors failed, providing a new treatment option for refractory uveitis.

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for non-infectious intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis in adults and pediatric patients 2 years and older
First FDA-approved treatment for non-infectious uveitis
FDA approved for symptomatic relief - blocks nerve impulses to ease pain and photophobia
Off-label use - chimeric monoclonal antibody targeting TNF-alpha
FDA approved biosimilar to Humira for uveitis indication

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Treatment typically starts with topical corticosteroids for local inflammation control, with adalimumab (TNF inhibitor) as FDA-approved systemic therapy for non-infectious intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis when topical treatment is insufficient
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited FDA-approved systemic options with only adalimumab specifically approved for uveitis, significant risk of vision loss if inadequately treated, and need for long-term immunosuppression with associated risks
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: The uveitis treatment market is dominated by Humira (adalimumab) as the only FDA-approved systemic biologic, with corticosteroids as first-line topical therapy. Significant unmet need exists for additional targeted therapies given the limited approved options and chronic nature requiring long-term treatment.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape Iritis and Uveitis Medication - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/798323-medication

source.title: Case report: Effectiveness of Janus kinase inhibitors in the management of isolated noninfectious uveitis: a case series

patient_population.description: 3 patients (1 female, 2 male) aged 28-59 years with isolated noninfectious uveitis (anterior, intermediate, and posterior types)

efficacy.effect_size_description: complete remission in all patients with sustained response
efficacy.primary_endpoint: remission of uveitis
efficacy.endpoint_result: all 3 patients achieved remission lasting >1 year
efficacy.efficacy_summary: All three patients with refractory isolated noninfectious uveitis achieved complete remission after JAK inhibitor therapy. Mean visual acuity improved from 0.4 to 0.6 (Snellen), with sustained remission lasting over 1 year in all cases.

safety.safety_summary: No significant side effects were observed in any patients throughout the follow-up period. Only one patient experienced a slight temporary increase in liver transaminase levels.

extraction.key_findings: This is the first report documenting successful use of baricitinib and upadacitinib in isolated noninfectious uveitis, with all patients achieving sustained remission after failing conventional treatments.

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for non-infectious intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis in adults and pediatric patients 2 years and older
First FDA-approved treatment for non-infectious uveitis
FDA approved for symptomatic relief - blocks nerve impulses to ease pain and photophobia
Off-label use - chimeric monoclonal antibody targeting TNF-alpha
FDA approved biosimilar to Humira for uveitis indication

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Treatment typically starts with topical corticosteroids for local inflammation control, with adalimumab (TNF inhibitor) as FDA-approved systemic therapy for non-infectious intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis when topical treatment is insufficient
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited FDA-approved systemic options with only adalimumab specifically approved for uveitis, significant risk of vision loss if inadequately treated, and need for long-term immunosuppression with associated risks
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: The uveitis treatment market is dominated by Humira (adalimumab) as the only FDA-approved systemic biologic, with corticosteroids as first-line topical therapy. Significant unmet need exists for additional targeted therapies given the limited approved options and chronic nature requiring long-term treatment.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape Iritis and Uveitis Medication - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/798323-medication

source.title: Successful Treatment of Refractory Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis (SAPHO) Syndrome with Baricitinib, a Janus Kinase Inhibitor

extraction.disease: SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis)

patient_population.description: 32-year-old Chinese woman with refractory SAPHO syndrome presenting with recurrent osteoarticular pain for over one year and skin erythema pustulosis for 11 months

treatment.dose: 2 mg twice daily initially, then halved
treatment.duration: Initial treatment with improvement at 2 weeks, then dose halved and continued for 3 months

efficacy.duration_of_response: Sustained response for 3 months follow-up with no recurrence
efficacy.effect_size_description: VAS pain score decreased from 9 to 2, complete skin lesion resolution
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Improvement in skin lesions and osteoarticular pain
efficacy.endpoint_result: Complete resolution of skin lesions and significant relief of osteoarticular pain within 2 weeks
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib achieved rapid and complete resolution of both skin lesions and osteoarticular pain within 2 weeks in a patient with refractory SAPHO syndrome. Laboratory markers normalized and pain scores dramatically improved from 9 to 2 on VAS scale.

safety.safety_summary: No adverse effects were observed during treatment or follow-up period. The patient tolerated dose reduction well with continued efficacy.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib successfully treated refractory SAPHO syndrome with rapid onset of action and sustained response, suggesting JAK inhibition as a promising therapeutic approach for this rare autoimmune condition.

top_treatments.notes: Off-label use, case reports show effectiveness for SAPHO syndrome
Off-label use, case reports for acne fulminans with SAPHO
Off-label use, case reports for sacroiliitis in SAPHO
Off-label use, mentioned for acne fulminans treatment
Standard treatment, especially combined with debridement
Symptomatic relief for joint inflammation

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: No FDA-approved therapies exist. Treatment is primarily off-label with TNF-alpha inhibitors showing promise in case reports, combined with corticosteroids and supportive care for bone and joint manifestations
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: SAPHO syndrome has no FDA-approved treatments and relies entirely on off-label therapies. Treatment responses are variable and many patients experience chronic symptoms affecting bones, joints, and skin with limited therapeutic options
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: SAPHO syndrome represents a significant unmet medical need with no approved therapies, relying on off-label use of biologics like adalimumab and infliximab. The rare nature of the disease limits clinical trial development, leaving patients dependent on case report evidence and physician experience.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape Medical Reference - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1072815-treatment

source.title: Spatial proteomics identifies JAKi as treatment for a lethal skin disease.

patient_population.description: patients with toxic epidermal necrolysis

efficacy.effect_size_description: rapid cutaneous re-epithelialization and recovery
efficacy.primary_endpoint: cutaneous re-epithelialization and recovery
efficacy.endpoint_result: rapid cutaneous re-epithelialization and recovery in all 7 patients
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Treatment with JAK inhibitors including baricitinib was associated with rapid cutaneous re-epithelialization and recovery in all seven patients with TEN. This represents a potential breakthrough treatment for a previously fatal condition with no effective therapy.

safety.safety_summary: Treatment with JAK inhibitors was described as safe in all seven patients with TEN. No specific adverse events were reported in this case series.

extraction.key_findings: JAK inhibitors including baricitinib demonstrated potential as a curative therapy for TEN, a previously fatal skin condition with no effective treatment options.

top_treatments.notes: Off-label, most commonly used treatment
Off-label, case reports show efficacy
Off-label, controversial due to infection risk
Standard of care - wound care, fluid management

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Immediate discontinuation of causative drug, supportive care with wound management and fluid/electrolyte balance, followed by immunomodulatory therapy such as IVIG or cyclosporine
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: No FDA-approved specific treatments exist, high mortality rate (30-50%), reliance on off-label immunomodulatory therapies with limited evidence base
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Currently no FDA-approved specific treatments for TEN exist, with management relying on supportive care and off-label use of immunomodulatory agents. Significant unmet need exists for approved therapies given the high mortality and limited treatment options.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA Drug Safety Communications and Stevens-Johnson Syndrome Treatment Guidelines from https://www.fda.gov/drugs/drug-safety-and-availability/

source.title: Clinical and immunological study of Tofacitinib and Baricitinib in refractory Blau syndrome: case report and literature review

patient_population.description: 25-year-old woman with severe refractory Blau syndrome with granulomatous dermatitis, arthritis, and uveitis

efficacy.effect_size_description: maintained adequate control of disease activity
efficacy.primary_endpoint: clinical control of cutaneous, ocular, and joint manifestations
efficacy.endpoint_result: cutaneous, ocular, and joint manifestations remained stable
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib successfully maintained disease control after tofacitinib discontinuation. Patient remained stable with controlled cutaneous, ocular, and joint manifestations throughout the 4-month follow-up period.

safety.safety_summary: Baricitinib showed an adequate safety profile with mild lymphopenia observed at 4 months (800 cells/µl) but no discontinuation required. No serious adverse events reported during the treatment period.

extraction.key_findings: First reported successful use of baricitinib in Blau syndrome, maintaining disease control with acceptable safety profile after tofacitinib discontinuation due to severe lymphopenia.

top_treatments.notes: Off-label use for uveitis component, FDA approved for uveitis
Off-label use for autoinflammatory features
Off-label for dermatologic manifestations
Off-label immunosuppressive therapy
Off-label anti-inflammatory therapy

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Symptomatic management with immunosuppressive agents targeting inflammation in skin, joints, and eyes. Treatment is primarily off-label using drugs effective for related autoinflammatory conditions.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: No FDA-approved therapies specifically for Blau syndrome. Current treatments are off-label and provide only symptomatic relief without addressing underlying NOD2 dysfunction. Limited treatment options for this rare genetic autoinflammatory disorder.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Blau syndrome has no FDA-approved treatments, with management relying on off-label use of biologics and immunosuppressants used for related autoinflammatory conditions. Significant unmet need exists for targeted therapies addressing the underlying NOD2 genetic defect in this rare pediatric disorder.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA curriculum vitae documents mentioning Blau syndrome research and treatment approaches

source.title: Combination of Baricitinib and Phototherapy in Adults With Active Vitiligo: A Randomized Clinical Trial.

patient_population.description: adults with active and extensive vitiligo disease, the most severe form of vitiligo

efficacy.effect_size_description: 35.6 percentage point greater improvement in VASI score compared to placebo
efficacy.primary_endpoint: change in total Vitiligo Area Scoring Index (VASI) score
efficacy.endpoint_result: -44.8% change in VASI score for baricitinib group vs -9.2% for placebo group
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib combined with narrowband UV-B phototherapy demonstrated significant efficacy in treating severe active vitiligo. The treatment resulted in rapid and clinically meaningful repigmentation with a 44.8% reduction in VASI score compared to 9.2% with placebo.

safety.safety_summary: The abstract mentions tolerance of the combination therapy but specific safety data are not provided in the available text.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib combined with phototherapy provided clinically meaningful repigmentation in severe active vitiligo with 44.8% reduction in disease severity.

top_treatments.notes: FDA-approved for nonsegmental vitiligo in patients 12+ years
Off-label, standard first-line therapy
Off-label photochemotherapy
Off-label light therapy
Off-label, tacrolimus/pimecrolimus

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: JAK inhibitors in development, prostaglandin analogs, and melanocyte transplantation techniques in various clinical trial phases
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Topical therapies as first-line (corticosteroids, Opzelura), followed by phototherapy (NB-UVB, PUVA), with surgical options for stable, localized disease
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited treatment options with modest efficacy, slow response rates requiring months of treatment, and complete repigmentation achieved in minority of patients
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Opzelura is the only FDA-approved pharmacologic treatment for vitiligo, representing a significant advance but with limited efficacy. Substantial unmet need remains given modest response rates and lack of curative treatments for this psychologically impactful condition.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA Drug Approval Database and NIAMS - https://www.fda.gov/drugs/news-events-human-drugs/fda-approves-topical-treatment-addressing-repigmentation-vitiligo-patients-aged-12-and-older

source.title: Baricitinib in severe and refractory peripheral ulcerative keratitis: a case report and literature review

patient_population.description: 85-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis and secondary Sjögren's syndrome with severe refractory PUK requiring surgical repair of corneal perforation

efficacy.effect_size_description: Complete resolution of corneal ulceration and achievement of joint remission (DAS28-CRP improved from 4.1 to 2.1)
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Ocular and joint disease remission
efficacy.endpoint_result: Complete ocular and joint remission achieved
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Patient achieved complete ocular and joint remission within 2 weeks of baricitinib initiation. No new episodes of corneal ulcers occurred during 18 months of follow-up, with sustained disease control.

safety.safety_summary: Treatment was well tolerated with only mild alopecia reported as an adverse effect. No serious adverse effects or signs of disease reactivation occurred during 18 months of treatment.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated rapid and sustained efficacy in severe refractory PUK with corneal perforation, achieving complete remission within 2 weeks with excellent safety profile.

epidemiology.us_incidence_estimate: 0.2 to 3 per million population per year

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved corticosteroid, first-line systemic therapy
FDA approved corticosteroid, used for pulse therapy
FDA approved immunosuppressant, steroid-sparing agent
FDA approved immunosuppressant, steroid-sparing agent
FDA approved immunosuppressant, alternative steroid-sparing agent
FDA approved for RA and uveitis, used off-label for severe cases
FDA approved for RA, used off-label for refractory cases
FDA approved immunosuppressant, reserved for severe cases

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Stepwise approach starting with systemic corticosteroids for acute inflammation, followed by steroid-sparing immunosuppressants (cyclosporine, azathioprine, mycophenolate) for maintenance. TNF inhibitors and cyclophosphamide reserved for severe or refractory cases. Treatment of underlying systemic autoimmune disease is essential.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Significant unmet need exists as PUK is a sight-threatening condition with no specific FDA-approved therapies for this indication. Current treatments are repurposed from other autoimmune conditions, and many patients require prolonged immunosuppression with associated side effects. Risk of corneal perforation and vision loss remains high despite treatment.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Treatment relies on repurposed immunosuppressants and biologics approved for other autoimmune conditions, with corticosteroids and traditional DMARDs forming the backbone of therapy. Significant unmet need exists for PUK-specific therapies given the sight-threatening nature and limited treatment options for refractory cases.
standard_of_care.soc_source: NCBI StatPearls and Medscape clinical references

source.title: Baricitinib could improve the prognosis of anti-MDA5 antibody positive dermatomyositis associated interstitial lung disease.

extraction.disease: Anti-MDA5 antibody positive dermatomyositis associated interstitial lung disease

patient_population.description: 39 adult patients (71.8% female) with MDA5+ dermatomyositis-associated interstitial lung disease, mean age 47.6±11.5 years, median disease duration 4.5 months

efficacy.effect_size_description: HRCT score decreased from 115 to 97.5, FVC improved from 76.44% to 90.73%, serum ferritin decreased from 739.9 to 56.3 ng/ml
efficacy.primary_endpoint: clinical improvement including skin manifestations and respiratory symptoms
efficacy.endpoint_result: 31 patients (79.5%) had clinical improvement
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed significant improvement in clinical symptoms, lung function, and inflammatory markers in 79.5% of patients. Six-month survival was superior in the baricitinib group compared to controls (87.2% vs 70%). First-line baricitinib use showed even better survival outcomes compared to conventional therapy (84.6% vs 52.9%).

safety.safety_summary: Safety outcomes were not explicitly reported in detail in this retrospective study. No specific adverse events were mentioned in the available text.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated significant clinical improvement in 79.5% of MDA5+ dermatomyositis-ILD patients with improved survival outcomes, particularly when used as first-line therapy.

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for dermatomyositis in adults (July 2021)
Standard first-line therapy, off-label use
Steroid-sparing agent, off-label use
Steroid-sparing agent, off-label use
Off-label use for refractory cases

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: First-line treatment typically involves corticosteroids, followed by steroid-sparing immunosuppressants like methotrexate or azathioprine. IVIG (Octagam 10%) is reserved for refractory cases or when conventional therapy fails.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Dermatomyositis has significant unmet need with only one FDA-approved therapy (IVIG), limited treatment options, variable response rates, and reliance on off-label immunosuppressants with significant side effects. Many patients experience incomplete responses or disease progression despite treatment.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Dermatomyositis has a very limited treatment landscape with only Octagam 10% (IVIG) FDA-approved specifically for this indication as of 2021. The field relies heavily on off-label corticosteroids and immunosuppressants, creating substantial unmet need for effective disease-modifying therapies with better safety profiles.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA Orphan Drug Database and Medscape Dermatomyositis Treatment Guidelines - https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/opdlisting/oopd/

source.title: Baricitinib is potentially effective in the treatment of refractory livedoid vasculopathy

patient_population.description: 8 patients (mean age 21.1 ± 9.1 years, including 2 pediatric patients) with refractory livedoid vasculopathy resistant to conventional treatments

efficacy.time_to_response: mean remission time of 7.75 ± 3.45 weeks (range 3-13 weeks)
efficacy.effect_size_description: statistically significant improvement with large effect size, clinical score reduction of approximately 5.6 points on 8-point scale
efficacy.primary_endpoint: clinical score reduction (0-8 scale measuring pain, ulceration, and erythema)
efficacy.endpoint_result: mean clinical scores decreased from 7.0 ± 1.6 to 1.4 ± 1.2 (P < 0.01)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: All 8 patients showed significant clinical improvement with statistically significant reduction in clinical scores. Six patients achieved remission (clinical score ≤2) with improvements in erythema, ulceration, and pain.

safety.safety_summary: No adverse events were reported in any patient during follow-up. Treatment was well-tolerated with no severe side effects, including in the two pediatric patients.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated significant efficacy in treating refractory livedoid vasculopathy with 100% clinical improvement rate and 75% remission rate, with excellent safety profile.

top_treatments.notes: Off-label, German S1 guideline first-line therapy
Off-label, guideline-recommended first-line therapy
Off-label, case reports show effectiveness
Off-label, traditional anticoagulant option
Off-label, guideline-recommended

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: German S1 guideline recommends anticoagulation as first-line therapy, primarily with DOACs like rivaroxaban or low-molecular-weight heparins. JAK inhibitors and biologics are emerging as second-line options for refractory cases.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: No FDA-approved treatments exist for livedoid vasculopathy, making off-label therapy the only option. Long-term treatment is usually necessary and some patients continue to have ulcers despite treatment, significantly impacting quality of life.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Livedoid vasculopathy has no approved treatments, with all therapy being off-label anticoagulation primarily using rivaroxaban or low-molecular-weight heparins per German guidelines. Significant unmet need exists as patients require long-term therapy with variable response rates and continued ulceration despite treatment.
standard_of_care.soc_source: German S1 guideline and PubMed study - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/41264385/

source.title: Clinical experience and safety of Janus kinase inhibitors in giant cell arteritis: a retrospective case series from Sweden.

patient_population.description: Mean age 70.1 years (range 61-80), 60% women, all Caucasian, with GCA diagnosed by ACR criteria and/or imaging

treatment.dose: baricitinib 3.86 mg daily (range 2-4 mg), tofacitinib 10 mg daily

efficacy.effect_size_description: Significant reductions in CRP, ESR, and prednisolone dose requirements
efficacy.primary_endpoint: CRP reduction
efficacy.endpoint_result: Significant CRP reduction at 3 months (p=0.02) and 6 months (p=0.02)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: JAK inhibitors showed significant efficacy in treating GCA with sustained reductions in inflammatory markers and steroid-sparing effects. No GCA relapses were observed during treatment, and 73% of patients achieved therapeutic benefit at 6 months.

safety.safety_summary: Two patients experienced serious infections but JAK inhibitor therapy was retained or reintroduced after recovery. No cases of malignancy, gastrointestinal perforation, liver enzyme elevation, or herpes zoster were observed.

extraction.key_findings: JAK inhibitors demonstrated strong efficacy in steroid-refractory GCA with acceptable safety profile and significant steroid-sparing effects.

top_treatments.notes: First and only FDA-approved drug specifically for GCA
Standard of care, off-label use for GCA
Standard of care, off-label use for GCA
Steroid-sparing agent, off-label use
Used in refractory cases, off-label

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: First-line treatment with high-dose corticosteroids followed by gradual tapering. Tocilizumab can be used as steroid-sparing therapy or following steroid discontinuation. Methotrexate and TNF inhibitors may be considered in refractory cases.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Only one FDA-approved drug available. High reliance on corticosteroids with significant long-term side effects. Limited options for steroid-sparing therapy and refractory cases.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Actemra (tocilizumab) is the only FDA-approved treatment for giant cell arteritis, with standard care still heavily reliant on corticosteroids. Significant unmet need exists for additional steroid-sparing therapies and treatments for refractory cases.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape Giant Cell Arteritis Medication and FDA Actemra approval documentation - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/332483-medication

source.title: Alopecia Areata Following the Use of Belimumab in a Patient with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and Arthritis Who Responded Well to Baricitinib: A Case Report.

patient_population.description: 54-year-old Saudi female with SLE presenting with mucocutaneous symptoms and arthritis, positive ANA and anti-dsDNA

efficacy.effect_size_description: significant improvement
efficacy.primary_endpoint: improvement in alopecia totalis and arthritis
efficacy.endpoint_result: significant improvement in alopecia totalis and arthritis
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib resulted in significant improvement in both alopecia totalis and arthritis symptoms in this SLE patient. The patient had failed multiple prior treatments including belimumab, steroids, and conventional DMARDs.

safety.safety_summary: No adverse events were reported with baricitinib treatment in this case report.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib effectively treated both alopecia totalis and arthritis in an SLE patient who had failed multiple conventional treatments including belimumab.

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for SLE and lupus nephritis
FDA approved for active lupus nephritis
Off-label, standard of care
Off-label immunosuppressant
Off-label for severe lupus
Off-label, commonly used for lupus nephritis
Off-label biologic
Off-label for severe manifestations

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: Several anti-CD20 antibodies, JAK inhibitors, and novel B-cell targeted therapies in Phase 2-3 trials for lupus nephritis and SLE
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Stepwise approach starting with antimalarials and NSAIDs, progressing to immunosuppressants and biologics for severe disease, with corticosteroids for flares
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Only 2 FDA-approved drugs for SLE, most treatments are off-label, significant reliance on corticosteroids with long-term toxicity, and many patients have inadequate response to current therapies
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: SLE has limited FDA-approved options with only Benlysta and obinutuzumab specifically approved, relying heavily on off-label immunosuppressants and antimalarials. Significant unmet need exists given the chronic nature of disease and limited efficacy of current treatments.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape eMedicine and Drugs.com - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/332244-treatment

source.title: Efficacy of Baricitinib in Patients with Refractory Adult-Onset Still’s Disease

patient_population.description: 7 female patients with refractory AOSD, median age 31 years, median disease duration 11 months

efficacy.effect_size_description: significant reduction in systemic score, CRP (p=0.0165), ferritin (p=0.0047), and prednisolone dose from 35.7±15.1 to 5.8±4.7 mg/day
efficacy.primary_endpoint: systemic score reduction and clinical improvement
efficacy.endpoint_result: significant systemic score reduction at 3 months (p=0.0216), 6 months (p=0.0007), and last follow-up (p=0.0007)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib provided rapid and durable clinical improvement in 6/7 patients with refractory AOSD, with significant reductions in disease activity scores, inflammatory markers, and steroid requirements. Five patients remained symptom-free at last follow-up.

safety.safety_summary: Treatment was generally well tolerated with mild lipid abnormalities being the most common adverse event. One patient discontinued due to progressive macrophage activation syndrome.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib showed strong efficacy in refractory AOSD with 85.7% response rate and significant steroid-sparing effects, with acceptable safety profile.

top_treatments.notes: FDA-approved for Adult-Onset Still's Disease and SJIA (2020)
Orphan designation but not FDA approved for Still's disease; widely used off-label
Off-label use; FDA-approved for related conditions including SJIA
FDA-approved for MAS in Still's disease (2025)
Standard first-line therapy but limited long-term efficacy
Off-label use as conventional DMARD

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Corticosteroids for initial management, with biologics (particularly IL-1 inhibitors) increasingly used as first-line therapy due to superior efficacy over conventional DMARDs
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited FDA-approved options, frequent relapses, significant side effects from corticosteroids, and potential for life-threatening complications like MAS
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Ilaris is the only FDA-approved biologic specifically for AOSD, with anakinra widely used off-label despite lack of FDA approval. Significant unmet need remains due to limited approved options and risk of serious complications requiring specialized treatments like emapalumab for MAS.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA Orphan Drug Designations and Approvals Database - https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/opdlisting/oopd/detailedIndex.cfm

source.title: Baricitinib decreases anti-dsDNA in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus: results from a phase II double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial

patient_population.description: Adults with SLE, mean age 43-45 years, 94% female, disease duration 10-12 years, baseline SLEDAI-2K score ~9

efficacy.time_to_response: as early as week 2 for 2mg dose, week 4 for 4mg dose
efficacy.effect_size_description: rapid and sustained significant decrease in anti-dsDNA antibodies and IgG levels
efficacy.primary_endpoint: median change from baseline in anti-dsDNA antibodies
efficacy.endpoint_result: significant decreases in anti-dsDNA: baricitinib 2mg -29.6 IU/mL, baricitinib 4mg -15.1 IU/mL vs placebo +3.0 IU/mL at week 24
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib demonstrated rapid and sustained reductions in anti-dsDNA antibodies compared to placebo, with effects beginning at weeks 2-4 and continuing through week 24. The 4mg dose also significantly reduced IgG levels at weeks 12 and 24.

safety.safety_summary: Safety outcomes were not reported in this analysis, which focused specifically on serologic biomarker changes from the phase II trial.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib significantly reduced anti-dsDNA antibodies and IgG levels in SLE patients, suggesting potential impact on B cell activity and autoantibody production.

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for SLE and lupus nephritis
FDA approved for active lupus nephritis
Off-label, standard of care
Off-label immunosuppressant
Off-label for severe lupus
Off-label, commonly used for lupus nephritis
Off-label biologic
Off-label for severe manifestations

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: Several anti-CD20 antibodies, JAK inhibitors, and novel B-cell targeted therapies in Phase 2-3 trials for lupus nephritis and SLE
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Stepwise approach starting with antimalarials and NSAIDs, progressing to immunosuppressants and biologics for severe disease, with corticosteroids for flares
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Only 2 FDA-approved drugs for SLE, most treatments are off-label, significant reliance on corticosteroids with long-term toxicity, and many patients have inadequate response to current therapies
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: SLE has limited FDA-approved options with only Benlysta and obinutuzumab specifically approved, relying heavily on off-label immunosuppressants and antimalarials. Significant unmet need exists given the chronic nature of disease and limited efficacy of current treatments.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape eMedicine and Drugs.com - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/332244-treatment

source.title: Baricitinib for refractory Takayasu arteritis: a prospective cohort study in a tertiary referral centre.

patient_population.description: Refractory Takayasu arteritis patients, median age 28 years, 9 female/1 male, median disease duration 50 months

efficacy.duration_of_response: 4/10 (40%) patients maintained overall treatment response during follow-up
efficacy.effect_size_description: 60% response rate at 6 months, 40% maintained response long-term, 80% of patients tapered or maintained same GC dose
efficacy.primary_endpoint: overall treatment response rate at 6 months
efficacy.endpoint_result: 6/10 (60%) patients had overall treatment response at 6 months
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib 4 mg daily achieved overall treatment response in 60% of refractory TAK patients at 6 months. During average 15.3 months follow-up, 40% maintained response and 80% were able to taper or maintain glucocorticoid doses.

safety.safety_summary: Baricitinib was well tolerated with only one patient (10%) discontinuing due to liver dysfunction. No other severe adverse events were reported during the study period.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib 4 mg daily is effective for refractory Takayasu arteritis with 60% response rate and good tolerability profile.

top_treatments.notes: Off-label, first-line standard of care
FDA-approved for giant cell arteritis
Off-label, steroid-sparing agent
FDA-approved for RA and other autoimmune conditions
Off-label, for refractory cases
Off-label, reserved for severe refractory disease

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: Upadacitinib (JAK inhibitor) recently received FDA approval for giant cell arteritis in 2025 and may be considered for Takayasu arteritis
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Corticosteroids as first-line therapy with gradual taper, combined with DMARDs for steroid-sparing effect. Biologics like tocilizumab or TNF inhibitors used for active disease or refractory cases. Cytotoxic agents reserved for severe, treatment-resistant disease.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited FDA-approved therapies specifically for Takayasu arteritis, reliance on off-label use of drugs approved for related conditions, significant steroid dependence and associated toxicity, and substantial number of patients with refractory disease requiring multiple immunosuppressive agents
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Only tocilizumab has FDA approval for the related condition giant cell arteritis, with most treatments being off-label use of corticosteroids, DMARDs, and biologics approved for other autoimmune conditions. Significant unmet need exists due to limited specific approvals, steroid toxicity, and refractory disease in many patients.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape Takayasu Arteritis Treatment & Management - https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/332378-treatment

source.title: A case of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis with a significant response to baricitinib: a first report with review of literature

patient_population.description: Patient with hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis

efficacy.effect_size_description: Significant response observed
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Clinical response to HLH treatment
efficacy.endpoint_result: Significant response
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Single patient with HLH showed significant response to baricitinib treatment. This represents the first reported case of baricitinib use in HLH.

safety.safety_summary: No safety information provided in the available case report details.

extraction.key_findings: First reported case of baricitinib showing significant efficacy in treating hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, supporting the rationale for JAK inhibition in this hyperinflammatory condition.

epidemiology.us_incidence_estimate: 1.2 cases per million persons per year

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for primary HLH with refractory, recurrent or progressive disease; also approved for HLH/MAS in Still's disease
Standard background therapy, off-label use
Standard combination therapy, off-label use
Conventional HLH-94/HLH-2004 protocol, off-label use

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Primary treatment involves immunosuppressive chemotherapy protocols (HLH-94/HLH-2004) with etoposide, dexamethasone, and cyclosporine A, followed by hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Emapalumab is used for refractory or progressive cases.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: High mortality rate despite treatment, limited treatment options for refractory disease, only one FDA-approved drug available, and significant toxicity from conventional chemotherapy protocols
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Gamifant (emapalumab) is the only FDA-approved treatment for primary HLH, representing a significant advancement for this rare and often fatal condition. Despite this approval, substantial unmet need remains due to high mortality rates, limited treatment options for refractory cases, and the need for less toxic therapeutic alternatives.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA accessdata.fda.gov and eMedicine clinical reference

source.title: Efficacy and Safety of Baricitinib Combined With Topical Corticosteroids for Treatment of Moderate to Severe Atopic Dermatitis: A Randomized Clinical Trial.

patient_population.description: Adults (mean age 33.8 years, 66% male) with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis with inadequate response to topical therapies

efficacy.effect_size_description: Significant improvement over placebo with both doses, 4mg showing numerically better response
efficacy.primary_endpoint: proportion of patients achieving vIGA-AD score of 0 (clear) or 1 (almost clear) with ≥2-point improvement at week 16
efficacy.endpoint_result: 31% with 4mg baricitinib + TCS, 24% with 2mg baricitinib + TCS vs 15% placebo + TCS
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Both 2mg and 4mg baricitinib combined with topical corticosteroids showed superior efficacy compared to placebo plus topical corticosteroids in achieving clear or almost clear skin. The 4mg dose showed numerically better response rates across multiple efficacy endpoints including EASI75/90 and itch reduction.

safety.safety_summary: The study reported an acceptable safety profile for baricitinib in combination with topical corticosteroids. Overall completion rate was high at 94% with 20 total discontinuations across all groups.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib combined with topical corticosteroids demonstrated superior efficacy to placebo plus topical corticosteroids in moderate to severe atopic dermatitis with acceptable safety profile.

top_treatments.notes: FDA-approved for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in patients 6 months and older
FDA-approved for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in patients 12 years and older
FDA-approved topical JAK inhibitor for mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis in patients 2 years and older
FDA-approved topical treatment for atopic dermatitis
FDA-approved topical treatment for atopic dermatitis
Multiple FDA-approved topical corticosteroids for atopic dermatitis
Recently FDA-approved for atopic dermatitis
Recently FDA-approved for atopic dermatitis
Recently FDA-approved for atopic dermatitis

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: BSI-045B (Biosion) in Phase II trials for atopic dermatitis, with additional JAK inhibitors and biologics in development
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Step-up approach starting with topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors for mild-to-moderate disease, progressing to topical JAK inhibitors, then systemic biologics (dupilumab, tralokinumab) for moderate-to-severe disease not controlled with topical therapies
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Atopic dermatitis has multiple FDA-approved treatment options including topical therapies (corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, JAK inhibitors) and systemic biologics (dupilumab, tralokinumab) with good efficacy rates. While treatment options have expanded significantly, some patients still require better long-term management solutions and treatments with fewer side effects.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA NDA/BLA Multi-Disciplinary Review and Evaluation - https://www.fda.gov/media/189437/download

source.title: Case report: Dupilumab therapy for alopecia areata in a 4-year-old patient resistant to baricitinib
source.authors: LC, YW, MZ, JZ, XT, ML

patient_population.description: 4-year-old male with alopecia universalis for 3 years and allergic rhinitis, no other atopic diseases

efficacy.effect_size_description: No response - SALT score remained 0 throughout treatment
efficacy.primary_endpoint: SALT score improvement
efficacy.endpoint_result: No improvement in SALT score (remained 0) after 6 months
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed no efficacy in this 4-year-old patient with alopecia universalis after 6 months of treatment. The patient subsequently responded well to dupilumab therapy.

safety.safety_summary: No adverse events reported during baricitinib treatment. Patient was switched to dupilumab due to lack of efficacy.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib was ineffective for pediatric alopecia universalis in this case, suggesting some patients may be resistant to JAK inhibitor therapy.

epidemiology.us_prevalence_estimate: 6.7 million people in the United States

top_treatments.notes: FDA approved for severe alopecia areata in adults (2022)
FDA approved, limited efficacy in severe disease
Off-label, first-line for limited disease
Off-label use
Off-label, second-line treatment
Off-label, topical sensitizer

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: Deuruxolitinib (JAK inhibitor) recently FDA approved, other JAK inhibitors in development
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Treatment selection based on disease extent: intralesional corticosteroids for limited disease, systemic JAK inhibitors for severe disease (≥50% hair loss), with various off-label options as second-line therapy
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited efficacy of available treatments, with only one systemic FDA-approved option for severe disease showing modest response rates, and most treatments used off-label with variable efficacy
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Only two FDA-approved treatments exist: baricitinib for severe disease and intralesional corticosteroids for limited disease, both with modest efficacy. Significant unmet need remains with most patients relying on off-label treatments with variable and often disappointing results.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA Multidiscipline Review and Medscape Treatment Guidelines, https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/nda/2023/215830Orig1s000MultidisciplineR.pdf

source.title: Mixed results with baricitinib in biological-resistant adult-onset Still’s disease and undifferentiated systemic autoinflammatory disease

extraction.disease: Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) and undifferentiated systemic autoinflammatory disease

patient_population.description: Adults with refractory AOSD (2 patients meeting Yamaguchi criteria) and 1 patient with AOSD-like condition in context of myelodysplastic syndrome, all biological-resistant

treatment.duration: 8±2 weeks follow-up reported, with one patient followed for 15 months

efficacy.duration_of_response: 15 months for P1, 9 months for P3
efficacy.effect_size_description: Complete clinical and biochemical remission in responders with normalization of CRP and ESR
efficacy.primary_endpoint: clinical and biochemical remission
efficacy.endpoint_result: complete remission in 2/3 patients (P1 and P3), no response in 1/3 patients (P2)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Mixed results with baricitinib showing complete remission in 2 of 3 patients with biological-resistant AOSD. One patient achieved sustained remission on monotherapy for 15 months, while another patient showed no improvement despite 9 months of treatment.

safety.safety_summary: One serious opportunistic infection (Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia) occurred in a patient with underlying myelodysplastic syndrome. This represents the first reported case of PCP infection following baricitinib use.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib showed promise in biological-resistant AOSD with 2/3 patients achieving complete remission, but was associated with serious opportunistic infection in one patient.

top_treatments.notes: FDA-approved for Adult-Onset Still's Disease and SJIA (2020)
Orphan designation but not FDA approved for Still's disease; widely used off-label
Off-label use; FDA-approved for related conditions including SJIA
FDA-approved for MAS in Still's disease (2025)
Standard first-line therapy but limited long-term efficacy
Off-label use as conventional DMARD

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Corticosteroids for initial management, with biologics (particularly IL-1 inhibitors) increasingly used as first-line therapy due to superior efficacy over conventional DMARDs
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: Limited FDA-approved options, frequent relapses, significant side effects from corticosteroids, and potential for life-threatening complications like MAS
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Ilaris is the only FDA-approved biologic specifically for AOSD, with anakinra widely used off-label despite lack of FDA approval. Significant unmet need remains due to limited approved options and risk of serious complications requiring specialized treatments like emapalumab for MAS.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA Orphan Drug Designations and Approvals Database - https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/opdlisting/oopd/detailedIndex.cfm

source.title: Efficacy and safety of baricitinib in Japanese patients with autoinflammatory type I interferonopathies (NNS/CANDLE, SAVI, And AGS).

extraction.disease: Autoinflammatory type I interferonopathies (NNS/CANDLE, SAVI, AGS)

patient_population.description: 9 Japanese patients (55.6% female, mean age 26 years): 5 with NNS/CANDLE, 3 with SAVI, 1 with AGS

treatment.dose: Weight and eGFR-based dosing with dose escalation over 8 weeks
treatment.duration: 52 weeks (12-24 week primary period plus maintenance)

efficacy.effect_size_description: Modest improvement in daily symptom scores, substantial corticosteroid reduction in some patients
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Change in mean daily diary score (DDS) from baseline
efficacy.endpoint_result: DDS decreased 0.22 in NNS/CANDLE, 0.21 in SAVI at primary endpoint; 0.18 in NNS/CANDLE, 0.27 in SAVI at maintenance endpoint
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed clinical benefit in NNS/CANDLE and SAVI patients with decreased daily symptom scores and reduced corticosteroid requirements. The single AGS patient showed minimal improvement with slight increase in symptom scores.

safety.safety_summary: All patients experienced at least one adverse event. Three patients had serious adverse events, with one drug-related SAE and one fatal intracranial hemorrhage deemed unrelated to study drug.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated potential therapeutic benefit for rare autoinflammatory interferonopathies, particularly NNS/CANDLE and SAVI, with acceptable safety profile in this vulnerable population.

top_treatments.notes: Compassionate use program for Type-1 interferonopathies
Off-label use for autoinflammatory conditions
Off-label for inflammatory manifestations
Off-label for skin manifestations

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: Baricitinib (JAK inhibitor) available through expanded access program for rare Type-1 interferonopathies
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Symptomatic management with JAK inhibitors showing promise through compassionate use programs, supportive care for organ-specific manifestations
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: No FDA-approved therapies specifically for Type I interferonopathies; treatment relies on off-label use of immunosuppressants and experimental JAK inhibitors through compassionate use programs
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: No FDA-approved treatments exist for Type I interferonopathies, with management relying on off-label immunosuppressants and JAK inhibitors. Significant unmet need exists for targeted therapies addressing the underlying interferon pathway dysfunction.
standard_of_care.soc_source: FDA EUA Document for Baricitinib - https://www.fda.gov/media/144473/download

source.title: Drug Survival and Predictors of Systemic Treatment Outcome in Atopic Dermatitis: Data From a Nationwide Swedish Cohort.

patient_population.description: Swedish patients with atopic dermatitis, median age 28 years, 50% male, median baseline EASI score 10

efficacy.effect_size_description: Poor drug survival compared to other treatments
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Drug survival (time to treatment discontinuation)
efficacy.endpoint_result: 14.2% drug survival at 2 years
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed poor drug survival in atopic dermatitis with only 14.2% of patients remaining on treatment at 2 years. This was significantly worse than methotrexate with a hazard ratio of 1.96 for drug discontinuation.

safety.safety_summary: Safety data not specifically reported for baricitinib alone. Side effects were cited as one of the reasons for treatment discontinuation across all treatments.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib had the poorest drug survival among JAK inhibitors for atopic dermatitis treatment, with significantly higher discontinuation rates than methotrexate.

top_treatments.notes: FDA-approved for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in patients 6 months and older
FDA-approved for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in patients 12 years and older
FDA-approved topical JAK inhibitor for mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis in patients 2 years and older

FDA-approved topical treatment for atopic dermatitis

standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: Step-up approach starting with topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors for mild-to-moderate disease, progressing to topical JAK inhibitors, then systemic biologics (dupilumab, tralokinumab) for moderate-to-severe disease not controlled with topical therapies
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Atopic dermatitis has multiple FDA-approved treatment options including topical therapies (corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, JAK inhibitors) and systemic biologics (dupilumab, tralokinumab) with good efficacy rates. While treatment options have expanded significantly, some patients still require better long-term management solutions and treatments with fewer side effects.

source.title: Use of Baricitinib in a patient with treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum

patient_population.description: 78-year-old female with treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum and metastatic high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma

efficacy.duration_of_response: axilla and elbow ulcers remained healed at 13 weeks post-discontinuation, lower extremity ulcer recurred 4 weeks after discontinuation
efficacy.effect_size_description: complete resolution of 2 ulcers, partial improvement of 1 ulcer
efficacy.primary_endpoint: ulcer healing and size reduction
efficacy.endpoint_result: right lower extremity ulcer decreased in size, ulcers on right axilla and right elbow resolved completely
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib 4mg daily for 12 weeks led to complete resolution of ulcers on right axilla and elbow, and partial improvement of right lower extremity ulcer. However, the lower extremity ulcer recurred 4 weeks after discontinuation while axilla and elbow ulcers remained healed.

serious_adverse_events: methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus right knee septic arthritis
discontinuation_reasons: patient and oncology team decision to resume paclitaxel for cancer treatment
safety.safety_summary: Patient developed septic arthritis after discontinuation of baricitinib, though temporal relationship to drug unclear. No other adverse events specifically attributed to baricitinib were reported during treatment period.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib showed efficacy in treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum but recurrence occurred after discontinuation in one ulcer.

top_treatments.notes: First-line systemic therapy, off-label use
FDA-approved for inflammatory conditions including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis
FDA-approved for rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis
Off-label use for refractory cases
Second-line immunosuppressant, off-label
Steroid-sparing agent, off-label
Steroid-sparing agent, off-label

standard_of_care.pipeline_details: IL-23 inhibitors (risankizumab, guselkumab), JAK inhibitors, and PDE4 inhibitors are being studied in clinical trials
standard_of_care.treatment_paradigm: No uniformly effective therapy exists. Treatment involves anti-inflammatory agents including corticosteroids as first-line, followed by immunosuppressants and biologic agents. TNF-alpha inhibitors are used for refractory cases.
standard_of_care.unmet_need_description: No specific therapy is uniformly effective for pyoderma gangrenosum. Many patients require multiple treatment attempts, and the disease can recur with residual scarring being common.
standard_of_care.competitive_landscape: Limited FDA-approved options exist specifically for pyoderma gangrenosum, with treatment relying primarily on off-label use of immunosuppressants and biologics approved for related inflammatory conditions. Significant unmet need exists due to lack of uniformly effective therapies and high recurrence rates.
standard_of_care.soc_source: Medscape - Pyoderma Gangrenosum Treatment & Management, https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1123821-treatment

source.title: Long-term Outcomes of New Systemic Agents in Atopic Dermatitis: Drug Survival Analyses and Treatment Patterns in Daily Practice.

patient_population.description: Adult patients with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, median age 42 years, 97.6% had previously received traditional systemic immunosuppressants

treatment.duration: median 4 months when discontinued, median 6.5 months when continued

efficacy.effect_size_description: Lowest survival rate among all treatments studied
efficacy.primary_endpoint: drug survival rate
efficacy.endpoint_result: 18-month drug survival rate of 20.4%
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed the lowest 18-month drug survival rate at 20.4% among all treatments studied. The majority of discontinuations (59.7%) were due to ineffectiveness, indicating poor treatment durability in this population.

safety.safety_summary: Of the 44 patients who discontinued baricitinib, 11 (17.7%) discontinued due to adverse events. Dose reduction was successful in only 6.5% of treatment courses, suggesting limited tolerability optimization options.

extraction.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated the poorest drug survival among all advanced systemics for atopic dermatitis, with highest discontinuation rate due to ineffectiveness.

top_treatments.notes: FDA-approved for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in patients 6 months and older

FDA-approved topical JAK inhibitor for mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis in patients 2 years and older
